newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-MADDUX, JOHNSON NAMED ALL-STAR STARTING PITCHERS.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-MADDUX, JOHNSON NAMED ALL-STAR STARTING PITCHERS.

text.p: Four-time Cy Young Award winner Greg Maddux of the Atlanta Braves and strikeout king Randy Johnson of the Seattle Mariners Monday were named starting pitchers for Tuesday's 68th All-Star Game.
Maddux, who has not pitched since throwing a masterful three-hit shutout against the New York Yankees last Wednesday, will be making his second All-Star start.
"It's a tremendous honour," said Maddux, one of seven Braves in the All-Star Game. "A lot of guys are having good years. I'm rested, I'm ready to pitch and I'm happy to be here."
Maddux is 11-3 with a 2.36 ERA in 18 starts with four complete games and two shutouts.
"If it's possible, this guy is getting better," said Braves and National League All-Star manager Bobby Cox, who selected Maddux as the NL starter.

Yankees manager Joe Torre, who is managing the American League stars, could not select AL wins and ERA leader Roger Clemens of the Toronto Blue Jays as his starter because "The Rocket" pitched Sunday.
Clemens boasts a 13-3 record and a remarkable 1.69 ERA.
But Torre doesn't loose much by going with Johnson, who leads the majors with 168 strikeouts so far this season.
Johnson, who has not pitched since Friday at Anaheim, made his first All-Star start in 1995, but he called this selection more special after working his way back from off-season back surgery.
"This is a form of reward for all the hard work it took to come back from the surgery," said Johnson. "It's really special to be here."
Johnson, who is 12-2 with a 2.20 ERA in 18 starts this season, is the fourth Mariner in the AL starting lineup.
Outfielder Ken Griffey, who has missed the last two All-Star games due to injuries, was voted in by the fans along with shortstop Alex Rodriguez and designated hitter Edgar Martinez.
The All-Star festivities begin Monday at Jacobs Field with Workout Day, a warmup for fans that includes a celebrity softball game, batting practice and a home run hitting contest.

Larry Doby, who 50 years ago broke the American League "color barrier" with Cleveland shorly after Jackie Robinson became the first black player in the major leagues with the National League Brooklyn Dodgers, is the honorary AL captain.
Frank Robinson, a one-time manager of the Indians, has the distinction for the NL.
The National League has won the last three All-Star Games and leads the all-time series, 40-26-1.
